admreg: Europe and Central Asia,Europe and Central Asia
trustfund:
TF038774-ARMENIA - SUPERVISION OF
            PRIMARY HEALTH CARE PROJECTS,TF036025-RUSSIA - MEDICAL EQUIPMENT,TF021993-PHRD-HEALTH PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings show satisfactory
            outcomes, likely sustainability, though only modest
            institutional development impacts. Several lessons were
            drawn from the project, the most important are as follows.
            The simplicity of project design reiterates its value, in
            that it allowed a quick, and visible impact on the health
            sector, but at the same time remained consistent with
            broader reform objectives. Moreover, this simplicity allowed
            undertaking the large-scale project over half the territory
            of Russia, in particular, providing the chance for using a
            single procurement agent, a consolidating, and a forwarding
            agent, thus easing the Russian Health Care Foundation's
            performance, which was outstanding in planning, and managing
            daily operations. Notwithstanding the merit of the selection
            criterion for less affluent regions, counterpart funding
            suffered not only because of weak political will to invest
            in the health sector, but because as it turned out, such
            regions by and large, had less availability of counterpart
            funds to provide. Rather, all regions should have been
            requested to share funding, and then select only those that
            would have done so. Furthermore, given the objective for a
            fast disbursement, had guidelines been provided early on to
            health facilities, better investment decisions would have
            been made overall. Other lessons address improved
            procurement practices, particularly as it concerns equipment
            packaging; balancing the choice between struggling local
            industries, and the need to ensure quality of supplies and
            equipment; and, strengthened institutional arrangements to
            sustain policy reforms.
